head_text.subj: INT. MADAME DE MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY

text: The gilt frame around the mirror on the MARQUISE DE MERTEUIL's dressing-table encloses the reflection of her beautiful face. For a moment she examines herself; critically, but not without satisfaction. Then she begins to apply her make-up. ANOTHER ANGLE shows the whole large room, the early : afternoon light filtering through gauze curtains. MERTEUI CHAMBERMAID stands behind her, polishing her shoulders wi crushed mother-of-pearl. Three or four other female SERVA wait, disposed around the room. It's midsummer in Paris i 1788.

head_text.subj: INT. VICOMTE DE VALMONT'S BEDROOM DAY

text: VALMONT is an indistinct shape in his vast bed. His valet de-chambre, AZOLAN leads a troupe of male SERVANTS into t room. One raises the blind and opens enough of a curtain to admit some afternoon light, another waits with a cup o chocolate steaming on a tray, a third carries a damp flan in a bowl. As VALMONT stirs, his face still unseen, AZOLA takes the flannel, leans over and begins a perfunctory dr wash.
A steel hook moves to and fro, deftly tightening MME DE MERTEUIL's corset.

VALMONT's face is swathed in hot towels, his head tilted A young MANICURIST, on his knees, attends to VALMONT's na Several other SERVANTS wait gravely to play their part in elaborate ritual of dressing VALMONT. The BARBER produces a pair of tweezers and delicately plucks a hair from one VALMONT's nostrils.
A second dressing-table is covered with extravagant numbe perfume boxes. MERTEUIL, now in corset, chemise and under sits, surrounded by her MAIDS. Eventually she makes a cho

10 ll Continued and indicates a box. A MAID opens the box and begins to apply the perfume (in the form of a cream) to MERTEUIL's lightly massaging it in. Meanwhile, MERTEUIL smells the contents of another box and hands it to a second MAID, wh begins applying it to MERTEUIL's armpit.

AZOLAN opens a walk-in closet, which contains innumerable of boots and shoes. He and another SERVANT choose a coupl pairs of shoes each and bring them out. VALMONT's hand co INTO SHOT, indicating a black pair with red heels. AZOLAN hands them to a BOOTBOY, who hurries away, breathing on t as he goes.
MERTEUIL'S MAID makes a final adjustment to the bamboo si panniers hanging from MERTEUIL's waist, then motions two MAIDS to cover them with an embroidered petticoat.

head_text.subj: INT. ANTE-ROOM TO VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY

text: VALMONT's PERRUQUIER waits attentively as VALMONT, seen from behind, stands in front of the three tiers of featur wooden heads which carry his collection of wigs. Eventual he points to one.

MERTEUIL's stomacher is now in position and she stands, a outstretched, as two MAIDS move forward with her dress, g her arms into it as if it were an overcoat. This done, MERTEUIL's SEAMSTRESS approaches and begins the delicate process of sewing her into her dress.

head_text.subj: INT. ANTE-ROOM TO VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY

text: A bizarre metal cone with gauze-covered eyeholes conceals VALMONT's face as the PERRUQUIER blows powder at his wig. the powder drifts away, VALMONT slowly lowers the cone an we see for the first time his intelligent and malicious features. ANOTHER ANGLE shows the complete magnificent ensemble; or not quite complete, for AZOLAN now reaches his arms round VALMONT's waist to strap on his sword.

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S TOWN-HOUSE DUSK

text: A panoramic view of the great room. In one corner MERTEUI is playing piquet with her cousin MME DE VOLANGES; in the centre of the room, the huge chandelier has been lowered within a foot of the floor and two FOOTMEN with tapers ar lighting its candles; and at the window itself is a demur 15-year-old blonde: CECILE VOLANGES. The CAMERA closes in on her, as ON SOUND we hear the arri of a carriage, clattering into the paved courtyard below.

CECILE'S P.O.V.: below, the handsome black carriage comes to a halt. The FOOTMAN clinging to the back jumps down, runs back, opens the door, lowers the step and stan back. Presently the VICOMTE DE VALMONT emerges, resplende

CLOSE ON CECILE, as she looks down at VALMONT, curious. The chandelier is fully lit now and one of the FOOTMEN begins to raise it. MME DE MERTEUIL's perfect, mask-like face gradually becom fully-lit as the chandelier rises. She's looking not at her cards but across the long expanse of the room at CECI profile. Eventually she speaks.
Well, my dear... CECILE doesn't at first realise it's she who's being addressed: then she starts and half-turns.
So how are you adapting to the outside world?
Very well. I think.
I've advised her to watch and learn and be quiet except when spoken to. MERTEUIL looks CECILE up and down, frankly appraising her
We must see what we can devise for your amusement. The mirrored double-doors open and MERTEUIL's MAJORDOMIO, carrying a silver tray, advances unhurriedly across the r

Continued At the table, the large playing cards slap down on one another. MERTEUIL glances up at her MAJORDOMO and reaches for the card on his tray. She replaces the card, looks up at him and nods. The MAJORDOMO departs and MERTEUIL speak quietly to VOLANGES.
Valmont is here. VOLANGES reacts with a trace of alarm.
You receive him, do you?
Yes. So do you. VOLANGES turns to her daughter, whose interest has been caught by this exchange.
Monsieur le Vicomte de Valmont, my child, whom you very probably don't remember, except that he is conspicuously charming, never opens his mouth without first calculating what damage he can do.
They why do you receive him, Maman?
Everyone receives him. She breaks off as the MAJORDOMO reappears, escorting VALMONT, who crosses to bow formally to MERTEUIL in a ges which also takes in the’ others.
Madame.
Vicomte.
What a pleasant surprise.
Madame de Volanges. How delight- ful to see you.
You remember my daughter, Cecile?
Continued
Well, indeed, but who could have foretold she would flower so gracefully? CECILE simpers, blushing and looking away. VALMONT turns back to MERTEUIL.
I wanted to call on you before leaving the city.
Oh, I'm not sure we can allow that. Why should you want to leave?
Paris in August, you know: and it's time I paid a visit on my old aunt, I've neglected her . disgracefully.
Madame de Rosemonde has been good enough to invite us to stay at the chateau. Will you please give her our warmest regards?
I shall make a point of it, Madame. VOLANGES puts down her cards and rises decisively, addressing CECILE.
I think it's time we took you home. CECILE responds, still nervously aware of VALMONT's unwavering stare. ’
I'm used to being in bed by nine at the convent.

So I should hope. She breaks away, mysteriously alarmed, and hurries across to VOLANGES. WMERTEUIL has summoned a FOOTMAN. VALMONT bows and we watch from his P.O.V. as the FOOTMAN shows ou VOLANGES and CECILE. When they've gone, MERTEUIL crosses back towards VALMONT, speaking in an entirely different t of voice.
Continued
Your aunt?
That's right,
I thought she'd already made arrangements to leave you all her money. He smiles without answering. She arrives beside him. Silence.
Do you know why I summoned you here this evening?
I'd hoped it might be for the pleasure of my company.
I need you; to carry out a heroic enterprise. You remember when Bastide left me? VALMONT feigns a sympathetic expression.
Yes.
And went off with that fat mistress of yours whose name escapes me.
Yes, yes.
No one has ever done that to me before. Or to you I imagine.
I was quite relieved to be rid of her, frankly.
No, you weren't. She now has his undivided attention.
For some years now, Bastide has been searching for a wife. He was always unshakeably prejudiced in favour of convent education. and now he's found the ideal candidate.
INT. CONVENT Day CECILE, superintended by a couple of NUNS, waits inside a enclosure, her face framed between the bars of a wooden Partition. a VALMONT (V.0.) Cecile Volanges.
Very good.
MME DE VOLANGES's magnificent carriage, silhouetted again the walls of the convent.
And her sixty thousand a year, that must have played some part in his calculations. ANOTHER ANGLE. A FOOTMAN helps MME DE VOLANGES down from the carriage.

None whatsoever. His priority, you see, is a guaranteed virtue. INT. CONVENT Day MME DE VOLANGES hasn't seen CECILE in years. She advances uncertainly towards her and they exchange a tentative emb through the partition.

I wonder if'I'm beginning to guess what it is you're intending to propose. A NUN opens the half-door to release CECILE. ‘ MERTEUIL (V.0.) Bastide is with his regiment in Corsica for the rest of the year.
That should give you plenty of time.
You mean to...?
She's a rosebud.  r 3 18 Continued
You think so?
i And he'd get back from honeymoon to find himself the laughing- stock of Paris.
Well...
Yes. Love and revenge: two of your favourites. | Silence. VALMONT considers for a moment. Finally, he shakes his head.
No, I can't.
What?
P) Really, I can't.
Why not?

It's too easy. It is. What is she, fifteen, she's seen nothing, she knows nothing, she's bound to be curious, she'd be on her back before you'd unwrapped the first : bunch of flowers. Any one of a dozen men could manage it. I. have my reputation to think of. MERTEUIL frowns, displeased. VALMONT hesitates, looking aft her.
I can see I'm going to have to tell you everything.
Of course you are.
cr ) Yes. Well. My aunt is not on her own just at the moment. She has a young friend staying with her: Madame dé Tourvel.
Continued
You can't mean it.

head_text.subj: EXT. FORMAL GARDENS OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S CHATEAU DAY

text: MME DE TOURVEL's strong, beautiful, untroubled face, as she moves through the gardens. She's accompanied. by VALM 80-year-old aunt, MME DE ROSEMONDE, who chooses flowers, which MME DE TOURVEL then cuts and lays in a basket.
To seduce a woman famous for atrict morals, religious fervour and the happiness of her marriage: what could possibly be more prestigious?
I think there's something degrading about having a husband for a rival. It's humiliating if you fail and commonplace if you succeed. Where is M. de Tourvel anyway?
Presiding over some endless case in Burgundy.
MERTEUIL frowns at VALMONT, shaking her head.
I don't think you can hope for any actual pleasure.

Oh, yes. And I have no intention of breaking down her prejudices. ‘ TY want her to boliovo im Coed and virtue and the sanctity of marriage and still not be able to stop herself. I want passion, in other words. I want the excitement of watching her betray everything that's most important to her. Surely you under- stand that. I thought betrayal was your favourite word.
No, no, cruelty: I always think that has a nobler ring to it. VALMONT smiles; but MERTEUIL turns on him, her expression serious.
Y a ° 10 20 Continued
I'm surprised at you. You might just as well be in love.
I haven't felt so strongly about t anything since you and I were together. That's why I intend to ’ have her, to rescue myself from this ridiculous position.

Love is something you use, not something you fall into, like ! quicksand, don't you remember? y It's like medicine, you use it ' as a lubricant to nature. He returns, a little uneasily, her challenging gaze.
-~ . The first-floor landing in MERTEUIL's house is an im 3) gallery of mirrors. She and VALMONT pass down the corr their images shifting and multiplying in the candle-light
How's Belleroche?
I'm very pleased with him.
And is he your only lover? MERTEUIL pretends to give this a moment's consideration.
Yes.
I think you should take another, I think it most unhealthy, this exclusivity.
You're not jealous, are you? ” VALMONT t ‘5 Of course I am. Belleroche is a completely undeserving.
I thought he was one of your closest friends.
il Continued
Exactly, so I know what I'm talking about. No, I think you should organise an infidelity. With me, for example.
You refuse me a simple favour and then you expect to be indulged?
It's only because it is so simple. It wouldn't feel like a conquest. I have to follow my destiny. I have to be true to my profession.
VALMONT pauses at the top of the broad and imposing stair which leads down to the entrance of the house. MERTEUIL watches him for a moment, amused: then she comes to an unexpected decision.
All right, then: come back when you've succeeded with Madame de Tourvel.
Yes?
And I will offer you...a reward.
My love.
But I shall require proof.
Certainly.
Written proof.
Ah.
Not negotiable. VALMONT recovers quickly.
22 23 24 25 26 12 Continued
I don't suppose there's any possibility of an advance?
Goodnight, Vicomte. He kisses her hand and hurries down the stairs.
MERTEUIL stops in front of one of the mirrors. It turns out to be a door, which she opens.
A candle at the top sheds a dim light; MERTEUIL begins to ascend her secret staircase.
BELLEROCHE, a beautiful blockhead of about 30, springs to his feet as MERTEUIL emerges from what is ostensibly a cupboard door. He hurries over to embrace her.
Where have you been? Time has no logic when I'm not with you: an hour is like a century.
I've told you before: we shall get on a good deal better if you make a concerted effort not to sound like the latest novel. He looks hurt; she kisses him affectionately.

head_text.subj: INT. PRIVATE CHAPEL IN MME DE ROSEMONDE'S GROUNDS DAY

text: The sound of the little silver bell which summons the congregation to take Communion: CLOSE ON MME DE TOURVEL as her hands part to reveal her face. MME DE ROSEMONDE kneels next to her and is now being helped to her feet by VALMONT. VALMONT escorts ROSEMONDE up the stairs to the altar-rail TOURVEL remaining on the other side of her. The rest of the congregation consists of ROSEMONDE's domestic staff, in a segregated portion of the chapel; and they file up towards the altar, respectfully waiting their turn.

13 Continued TOURVEL kneels at the altar-rail as VALMONT helps ROSEMON to kneel beside her. Then TOURVEL looks up, slightly surprised, as VALMONT moves off to one side, instead of taking his place at the rail. By now, the elderly CURE, intoning the Latin mass, is approaching TOURVEL with the large Communion wafer. VALMONT watches intently. VALMONT'S P.O.V.: the wafer is placed on TOURVEL's lower lip and slowly vanishes into her mouth. She looks up at h TOURVEL'S P.O.V.: VALMONT, his expression respectful, his demeanour hunble.

Beautiful summer's day. The chapel is in the grounds of MME DE ROSEMONDE's chateau, the turrets of which are visi in the distance. Her open carriage stands waiting, as the congregation emerges into the sunlight. The COACHMAN jump down, but MME DE ROSEMONDE dismisses him with a gesture.

It's such a beautiful day, I believe we'll walk. AZOLAN attends to VALMONT, taking his prayer-book and handing him his cane; while MME DE TOURVEL's chambermaid, JULIE, is helping her mistress with her bonnet.
MME DE ROSEMONDE and the CURE lead the way, deep in conversation, followed at a distance by VALMONT and MME D TOURVEL. AZOLAN and JULIE bring up the rear.
You didn't take the sacrament today.
I felt L couldn't.
May I ask why?
I have this appalling reputation as you may know...
Oh, yes, I have been warned about you. .
28 29 30 14 Continued
You have? By whom?
A friend.
Yes, well, I suppose a warning might be justified. I've spent my life surrounded by immoral people; I've allowed myself to be influenced by them and sometimes even taken pride in outshining them.
And now?
Now what I feel most often is unworthiness.

But it's precisely at such moments you start to become worthy. VALMONT appears to give this assertion his serious consideration. He glances back over his shoulder and notices that AZOLAN is murmuring with some intimacy into JULIE's ear. Then he turns back to MME D= TOURVEL.

I certainly believe that one should constantly strive to improve oneself. LONG SHOT of the two of ‘them, strolling along the dapple path, as, on SOUND, the passionate climax of a Gluck aria begins to swell.

head_text.subj: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT THE OPERA EVENING

text: The aria continues, the opera is in progress. MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE, in the box, stare down at the Stage. MME DE MERTEUIL, however, opera-glasses pressed to her fa is scanning the audience.
MERTEUIL'S P.O.V., as her gaze comes to rest on the face of a handsome young man of not more than twenty, listenin intently, tears streaming down his face: the CHEVALIER DANCENY.
MERTEUIL lowers her opera-glasses, pensive.

The interval, and the fashionable audience goes about its principal business of the evening: gossip and celebrity- spotting. DANCENY moves through the auditorium, still in something of a trance; and is startled by the arrival of a uniformed FOOTMAN, who hands him a note on a silver tra
A knock at the door and DANCENY, charmingly shy and uncer bows deeply to MERTEUIL.

Chevalier, I don't. believe you know my cousin, Madame de Volanges. This is Chevalier Danceny. And Madame's daughter, Cecile. All this has taken place very quickly and now DANCENY bec aware of CECILE for the first time: he looks at her, tong tied, obviously smitten, eventually managing to utter a strangled greeting. MERTEUIL observes him shrewdly.
Tell us what we should think of the opera.
Oh, it's sublime. Don't you find?
Why do these composers keep choosing identical subjects?
But this is infinitely the better ‘ version. Piccini is a mere opportunist.
Monsieur Danceny is one of those rare eccentrics who come here to listen to the music.
I do look forward to our next meeting. He bows to CECILE, blushing deeply and leaves the box. CECILE's eyes are shining. MERTEUIL is watching her closely.
16 Continued
Charming young man. Penniless, regrettably. He's one of the finest music-teachers in the city. CLOSE on CECILE: the idea occurs to her at the very moment MERTEUIL expresses it.
Perhaps you should employ him.

head_text.subj: EXT. GROUNDS OF THE CHATEAU DAWN

text: VALMONT and AZOLAN, who carries a long musket over his shoulder, crunch across the gravel. As they pass, a PAN reveals MME DE TOURVEL's footman, GEORGES, following them huddled in an angle of the building.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. MME DE TOURVEL'S BEDROOM DAWN

text: MME DE TOURVEL stands, a corner of the curtain raised, looking down at VALMONT and AZOLAN.
VALMONT speaks abruptly to AZOLAN, surprising him in mid- yawn.
How are you getting on’ with Madame de Tourvel's maid?

Julie? Tell you the truth, it's been a bit boring. Lf I wasn't so anxious to keep your Lordship abreast, I think I'd have only bothered the once. Still, you know, what else is there ‘ to do in the country?
Yes, it wasn't so much the details of your intimacy I was after, it was whether she's agreed to bring me Madame de Tourvel's letters.
She won't steal the letters, sir.
She won't?
36 37 38 39 17 Continued
You know better than me, sir, it's easy enough making them do what they want to do; it's trying to get them to do what you want them to do, that's what gives you a headache.
And them, as often as not. I need to know who's writing to her about me.

I shouldn't worry if I was you, sir. She told Julie she didn't believe you went hunting in the mornings. She said she was going to have you followed. So I'd say it was only a matter of time. They carry on through the woods. Behind them, GEORGES blunders incompetently from tree to tree.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY

text: AZOLAN unlocks a gate in the wall enclosing ROSEMONDE's property to let VALMONT through. The latter hesitates, looking back.
Terrible noise he's making.
He'll get the news back to her twice as quickly.
I don't think we should make ’ . it too easy for him. He takes the musket from AZOLAN and suddenly fires it into the undergrowth.
GEORGES, panic-stricken, hurls himself to the ground as the echoes of the shot die away.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY

text: VALMONT hands the musket back to AZOLAN and closes the ga behind them. The wall stretches away as far as the eye ca see. The two men grin at each other and hurry on.

The village consists of half-a-dozen wattle-and-daub huts, disposed around a muddy clearing; where pigs graze and bare-foot children wander. The poverty is as stark an absolute as that of a village in India. A small crowd is gathered around one of the huts, out of which a couple of MEN, supervised by the BAILIFF are carrying out a plain deal table, which they dump down next to three wooden cha A gaunt WOMAN follows them, miserably wringing her hands. GEORGES hurries across the square, reaching the fringes o the crowd just as VALMONT steps forward to confront the BAILIFF.
What exactly do you think you're doing?
I am impounding these effects, sir.
Has it not been explained to you? M. Armand is not well. BAILIFF . I don't make the laws, sir, I just do what I'm told. Everybody has to pay his taxes.
How much does he owe?
Well...
How much?
Fifty-six livres. VALMONT takes a large, jingling purse out of his pocket and hands it to AZOLAN.
Pay him.
Yes, my lord. Gasps from the crowd; even a ripple of applause. VALMONT marches forward and vanishes into the hut.  41 42

19 INT. ARMAND'S HUT Day Standing on the straw spread over the mud floor, in the heat of the more or less unventilated, dingy hut, looking down at M. ARMAND, (a man of not more than 50, who looks ancient, gnarled and battered by work, with long, thick white hair), VALMONT has to make an effort not to be overcome by the fetid atmosphere.
You don't know me...
Of course I do, M. le Vicomte.
Ah. No, please, don't get up. ARMAND is struggling up-.out of his large pallet bed covered with sacking.
I have to, sir. They're taking the bed.
Not at all, M. Armand. No one is taking anything.
The crowd scatters as VALMONT emerges from the hut. He approaches the BAILIFF.

Kindly instruct your men to replace M. Armand's furniture. The gaunt WOMAN approaches VALMONT; she's accompanied by a toil-worn younger COUPLE and a pair of thin, sickly- looking CHILDREN. ‘ WOMAN You're an angel sent from heaven. Suddenly, all of them are on their knees to VALMONT. Genuinely touched, he. looks across at AZOLAN, then manag to free a hand to reach for his purse. AZOLAN passes it to him and he fetches out a handful of gold, pressing it into the WOMAN's reluctant hand.
Just to tide you over. IL insist. Again the crowd bursts into spontaneous applause. GEORGES watches thoughtfully. .

head_text.subj: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY

text: AZOLAN unlocks a compartment in one of the brick gatepost and takes out a wooden mailbox with a slot in the top. Then he takes a pin from his wig and begins delicately to probe the loek of the mailbox as they talk.
Fifty-six livres to save an entire family from ruin, that seems a genuine bargain.

These days, my lord, you can find half-a-dozen like that, any village in the country. VALMONT oe Really? I must say the family was very well chosen. Solidly respectable, gratifyingly tearful, no suspiciously pretty girls. Well done. :
I do my best for you, sir.

And all that humble gratitude. It was most affecting. AZOLAN “ Certainly brought a tear to my eye. The lock yields to his manipulations, the mailbox opens a after a brief inspection he hands two letters to VALMONT, who glances at the postmarks and hands one of them straig back to AZOLAN. .
Dijon. That's from her husband. He holds the other letter which is ina distinctive, somewhat pretentious envelope, up to the light.
I'm sure this must be from that officious friend of hers. He passes it back to AZOLAN, who returns it to the mailbo and closes it. They move off, back in the direction of th house.
Tell me, where do you and Julie meet? . AZOLAN non Oh, in my room, sir.
21 Continued
And is she coming tonight?
Afraid so.
Then I think I may have to burst in on you. See if blackmail will succeed better than bribery. About two o'clock suit you? I don't want to embarrass you, will that give you enough time?
Ample, sir. In the background GEORGES has come through the gate. He unlocks the mailbox and takes out the letters it contains.

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND SALON IN THE CHATEAU DAY

text: VALMONT looks up from his book, as MME DE ROSEMONDE bustl into the room, followed by MME DE TOURVEL. He rises to greet them.
Is this true about M. Armand?
I don't believe I know anyone of that name...
You may as well own up, Monsieur. My footman happened to be passing when you were in the village this morning. ‘ VALMONT I don't think you ought to pay too much attention to servants gossip.
It is true, isn't it?
Well, I...it's simply...Yes. He looks up, ostensibly deeply embarrassed, to catch MME TOURVEL's admiring gaze. MME DE ROSEMONDE spreads her arm
You dear boy. come and let me give you a hug!

22 Continued VALMONT crosses to her and they embrace. Then VALMONT turns and advances towards MME DE TOURVEL. Before she can escape, he's embraced her and, for a second, she's in his arms. Meanwhile MME DE ROSEMONDE's STEWARD has entered, with the mail laid out on a salver. As MME DE. TOURVEL escapes from VALMONT's arms, she finds the STEWAR at her elbow. Ashen, she shakily reaches out her hand for the two letters. INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE Day CECILE is playing the harp and singing a song, accompanie by DANCENY on the harpsichord. On the far side of the roo are MERTEUIL and VOLANGES, paying far more attention to their murmured conversation than to the music. After a ti DANCENY breaks off, hitting a note several times to indic where CECILE's voice has gone wrong. They resume a few ba back; this time CECILE gets it right and DANCENY nods in approval. They proceed until CECILE makes a mistake with harp. DANCENY stops and comes over to join her. He plays the complicated little phrase. CECILE tries it, but can't manage it. He takes her hands and adjusts them to the correct position. She almost plays the phrase correctly, looks up at him smiling.
Try it again. She does so and gets it right.

Very good. As he turns away, he slips a piece of paper between the h strings. CECILE frowns, then, as he arrives back at the harpsichord, she snatches it and unfolds it. On it is a message written in pencil: I LOVE YOU. Blushing furiously, she crumples the piece of paper and s it into her pocket. Then she darts an angry glance at DAN ’
This is very difficult, I'm afraid. Can we start again? He begins to play and CECILE, with a great effort, manage to come in almost on cue.

head_text.subj: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT. THE OPERA EVENING

text: The opera is in full swing. MERTEUIL and CECILE murmur to one another in the darkened box, neither paying the slightest attention to the stage below.  46 Continued
Would it be very wrong of me to answer M. Danceny's letters?
In the circumstances, yes.
In what circumstances? MERTEUIL pretends to reflect before answering.
It's not my place to tell you this, my dear...if I hadn't become so fond of you...
Go on, please!
Your marriage has been arranged. CECILE gapes at her: but this has not come as a total surprise and her curiosity quickly overcomes her alarm.
Who is it?
Someone I know, slightly. M le Comte de Bastide.
What's he like?
Well...
You don't like him.
It's not that. He's a man of somewhat...erratic judgment. And rather serious.
How old is he?
Thirty-six.
Thirty-six? He's an old man!
“) 46 47 24 Continued MERTEUIL smiles, as another thought galvanises CECILE.
Do you know when?
In the new year, I believe. She stares, unseeing, at the stage, lost in thought. MERTEUIL leans in closer to her.
Perhaps there is a way to let you write to M. Danceny...
Oh, Madame! She's caught hold of MERTEUIL's hand, her eyes shining.

If you were to show me both sides of the correspondence, I could reassure myself... CECILE throws herself into MERTEUIL's arms and embraces her. MERTEUIL's eyes glitter in the darkness. Then CECILE looks up at her.

I can't show you the letters I've already sent him... She breaks off, realising she's given herself away, her expression apprehensive. But MERTEUIL's smile is indulgen As the impassioned love-duet on stage reaches a climax, phe stretches out a hand to caress CECILE's neck and coll one.

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND SALON IN THE CHATEAU NIGHT

text: VALMONT is reading and MME DE TOURVEL is looking over her letter from Paris, the one with the distinctive envelope. Eventually, she looks up at him and breaks the silence.
I can't understand how someone whose instincts are so generous, could lead such a dissolute life.
I'm afraid you have an exaggerated idea both of my generosity and of my depravity. If I knew who'd given you such a dire account of me...

Maman?

MME DE ROSEMONDE is entertaining members of the local nobility and everyone has made an effort to do justice to the occasion. No.

Surely I've explained to you before how much I enjoy watching the battle between love and virtue.
What concerns me is that you appear to enjoy watching it more than you used to enjoy winning it.

I really don't want to hurry things: Every step she tries to take away from the inevitable conclusion brings her a little nearer to it. And when Bastide and Cécile are married and Madame de Tourvel eventually collapses, we shall tell everyone, shall we not?

I am grateful, of course: but that would have been almost insultingly simple. One does not applaud the tenor for clearing his throat. The pure and unearthly SOUND of a soprano VOICE raised in some religious anthem, as VALMONT and MERTEUIL join a reluctant MME DE VOLANGES.

The VOICE belongs to a tall MAN of melancholy aspect: a castrato. He stands on a dais in front of a small baroque orchestra, singing exquisitely, the veins standing out on his temples, to an attentive audience. VALMONT and MERTEUIL are in the back row, watching. Suddenly, however, VALMONT gives a quite perceptible star which MERTEUIL notices. She follows his eyeline. MME DE TOURVEL,looking frail and beautiful, has entered t room. Presently, MME DE TOURVEL half-turns to scan the crowd. S looking for VALMONT; and when she sees him she holds his and smiles shyly. VALMONT smiles back: MERTEUIL watches him, with a trace o alarm. MME DE TOURVEL turns back to listen to the music. VALMONT stares, rapt, at her profile. Then he starts agai as MERTEUIL's hand closes on his wrist. VALMONT is once again lost in contemplation of her profil He doesn't notice now that MERTEUIL is looking at him, he expression considerably disturbed.  cy u 85 86 87 88 89 58

VALMONT arrives late for the service. He's pleased to notice that the seat next to MME DE TOURVEL is empty. Indeed, as she turns and beckons to it, it's clear that s has saved it for him. He arrives, acknowledging her and kneels for a moment's private prayer.
VALMONT stands, still fully dressed, in his candle-lit bedroom, his door slightly ajar, his eye to the crack in the door.
VALMONT'S P.O.V. through the crack in the door; MME DE TOURVEL, alone, arrives at the top of the stairs.

VALMONT stops, as if surprised, and bows to MME DE TOURVE
Madame.

Yes.

59 Continued
Oh, yes. By this time, they've arrived at the door to her bedroom, which she's opened. She hesitates in the doorway and VALMONT decides to take a chance.

Of course. Trying to conceal his astonishment, he follows her into the room.
VALMONT speaks, to cover his entrance into the room, whic is similarly appointed to his own, though somehow far mor sober in feeling.

I see.

Oh, please. You must! It's an involuntary exclamation; VALMONT knows exactly how to capitalise on it.
Are you still so anxious to get rid of me?
You know the answer to that. I rely on your integrity and generosity. I want to be able to be grateful to you.
Forgive me if I say I don't want your gratitude. I want something altogether deeper.
Na} 90 60 Continued
I know God is punishing me for my pride. I was so certain nothing like this could ever happen.
Nothing like what?
I can't...
Do you mean love? Is love what you mean? He takes her hand. She starts, but doesn't remove it.
You promised not to speak of it.
But I must know, I need this consolation at least.
I can't...don't you see...it's impossible.

Of course I understand, I don't want you to Say anything, but I must know, I must know if you love me, don't speak, you don't have to speak. I just want you to look at me. Just look. That's all I ask. Long silence. Finally, slowly, MME DE TOURVEL raises her eyes to him. ’

Yes. They're motionless for a moment. Then. VALMONT releases her hand and puts his arms around her. As he does so, her eyes suddenly go dead and she collapses sideways, obligin him to catch her. She sways in his arms for a moment, the comes to and jerks violently away from him, running half- across the room. Then she bursts into tears. 90 91 92 61 Cont inued

For God's sake, you must leave me, if you don't want to kill me, you must help, it's killing me! VALMONT, somewhat taken aback at first by her intensity, collects himself and lifts her to her feet. For a moment they sway together in an ungainly embrace; then MME DE TOURVEL's sobs cease abruptly and give way to chattering teeth and almost epileptic convulsions. Startled, VALMONT gathers her up in his arms, carries her over and deposits her gently on the bed. The convulsions continue, her teeth are clenched, the blood drained from her face. He leans forward and loosens her bodice as she stares helplessly up at him. Slowly, her features return to normal. He looks down at her, perplexed. Her arms open, she relaxes, her lips part. He starts to lean towards her then suddenly checks himself and looks away, something almost like shame darkening his expression. Her face begi to collapse. He looks back at her, gnawing at his lip. Sh begins to go into shock again and he straightens up, move back across the room and pulls the bell-pull. Her sobs drive him from the room.
As VALMONT steps into the corridor, ROSEMONDE's maid, ADE comes hurrying up, struggling into her dressing-gown.
Fetch Madame. Madame de Tourvel has been taken ill. ADELE hurries away and VALMONT steels himself to step bac into the room.

As VALMONT appears in the doorway, TOURVEL stretches out her hand to him. He crosses and takes it between both of his. He stands, massaging her hand, bemused and thoughtfu He lets go of her hand abruptly as MME DE ROSEMONDE appea shepherded by ADELE.
I heard something as I was passing; she seemed to. be having difficulty breathing.
Oh, my dear, whatever is it?
I'm all right now.  y
92 93 94 95 62 Continued
I shall leave her in your capable hands, Aunt. And still looking strangely abashed, he leaves the room.
We must send for a doctor, my dear. MME DE TOURVEL is roused from her rapt contemplation of VALMONT's departure. :
No, no, please, I don't need a doctor. I just...come and sit by me for a moment.

As VALMONT moves back towards his room, lost in thought, he hears a footstep behind him. It's MME DE VOLANGES, on her way to investigate the disturbance. VALMONT makes an authoritative gesture to discourage her from entering TOU room, and she turns away, strangely confused and abashed.
VALMONT closes the door behind him and leans his head bac on it, completely mystified.
ROSEMONDE's kindly face looks anxiously down at MME DE TOURVEL. They're holding hands. ADELE has left the room. MME DE TOURVEL speaks very quietly, controlling herself with enormous difficulty.
I must leave this house. I'm most desperately in love. MME DE ROSEMONDE bows her head, unsurprised.
To leave here is the last thing in the world I want to do, but I'd rather die than have to live with the guilt. Can you understand what I'm saying?  u 95 Continued 63
Of course. My dear girl. None of this is any surprise to me. The only thing which might surprise one is how little the world changes.
Well, what should I do? What's your advice?
If I remember rightly, in such matters all advice is useless.
I've never been so unhappy.
I'm sorry to say this: but those who are most worthy of love are never made happy by it. You're too young to have understood that.
By why, why should that be?

Do you still think men love the way we do? No. Men enjoy the happiness they feel; we can only enjoy the happiness we give. They're not capable of devoting themselves exclusively to one person. So to hope to be made happy by love is a certain cause of grief. I'm devoted to my nephew, but what's true of most men is doubly so of him.
And yet...he could have...just now. He took pity on me, I saw it happen, I saw his decision not to take advantage of me.
If he has released you, my dear child, you must go. TOURVEL looks up at her. Tears. begin to cascade from the corners of her eyes.
AZOLAN leans over VALMONT, shaking him. VALMONT comes up from the bottom of a deep sleep and wakes with a start
Get up, sir, quick.

Over here. VALMONT, spurred by the urgency of his tone, scrambles out of bed and joins him at the window.
Below, a carriage pulls away and speeds down the entrance drive. . .
AZOLAN turns to the still slightly befuddled VALMONT.
Madame de Tourvel.
What? Suddenly, VALMONT is wide-awake. He issues his orders calmly and decisively. -

I want you to follow her, right now. Stay close to her. I want ' to know everything. Who she sees, where she goes, what she eats, if she sleeps. Everything. He's fetched what looks like a great deal of money out of his desk.
That's for bribes, Yours will come later,
Yes, sir.
Or not. Now go.  cy 98 99 100 101 65 Continued the shock beginning to show.

This, which Julie managed to get to before it was sealed up. It's to Father Anselme. She says he can bring you to see her. VALMONT has run his eye over the letter.

No visitors. There still hasn't been a single visitor since she got back.

text: VALMONT, pleased, is handing AZOLAN a fat purse.
How's Julie?
Seems a bit keener than she was in the country.
101 66 Continued AZOLAN sighs, shaking his head gloomily.
Talk about devotion to duty. VALMONT's MAJORDOMO shows MME DE MERTEUIL and DANCENY into the room. VALMONT dismisses AZOLAN, speaking out of the side of his mouth.
Off you go. Keep it up. AZOLAN and the MAJORDOMO leave as VALMONT greets his visitors.
Madame. My dear boy. DANCENY runs over to him and embraces him impulsively.
Thank you, Monsieur, for every- thing.
I was afraid I'd been a sad disappointment to you.
On the contrary, it's you I have to thank for keeping our love alive.
Ah, as to love, Cécile thinks of little else.
I had so hoped you'd be able to arrange a meeting between us in the country. ‘ VALMONT Yes. In many respects I found her very open to persuasion; but not, alas, on that issue.
She said in her letter I couldn't do more myself than you've been doing on my behalf.
She's a most generous girl.
u 101 Continued 67
I don't know how I can bear to go another two weeks without seeing her.
We shall have to do our very best to provide some distraction for you. And now if you'd be so kind as to wait in the carriage, there's a matter I must discuss with the Vicomte in private.
Of course. He bows to VALMONT and pumps his hand heartily.
I don't know how I can ever repay you.
Don't give it another thought, it's been delightful. . DANCENY leaves the room and VALMONT and MERTEUIL look at one another.
Poor boy. He's quite harmless.
I must say I thought Cécile's letter sounded unusually witty.
So I should hope: I dictated it.
Ah, Vicomte, I do adore you.
I have a piece of news I hope you might find entertaining: I have reason to believe the next head of the house of Bastide may be a Valmont.
What can you mean?
Cécile is two weeks late.  101 Continued 68 MERTEUIL is startled: she frowns, assessing the implicati
aren't you pleased?
I'm not sure.

Your aim was to revenge yourself on Bastide. I've provided him with a wife trained by me to perform quite naturally services you would hesitate to request from a professional and very likely pregnant as well. What more do you want?
All right, Vicomte, I agree, you've more than done your duty. Shame you let the other one slip through your fingers. VALMONT 's expression darkens.
I let her go. Can you imagine?
But why?
I was...moved.
Oh, well, then, no wonder you bungled it.
I had no idea she was capable of being so devious.
Poor woman, what else could you expect? To surrender and not be taken, it would try the patience of a saint.
I have an appointment to visit her on Thursday. And this time, I shall be merciless. I'm going to punish her.
I'm pleased to hear it.  Gy 101 102 103 69 Continued
Why do you suppose we only feel compelled to chase the ones who run away?
Immaturity?

I shan't have a moment's peace until it's over, you know. I love her, I hate her, my life's a misery; I've got to have her so I can pass all these feelings on to her and be rid of them. MERTEUIL is not best pleased by his tone.
I think I may have kept our young friend waiting long enough.
I shall call on you sometime soon after Thursday. .
Only if you succeed, Vicomte. I'm not sure I could face another catalogue of incompetence. She pecks him on the cheek and hurries away. VALMONT watches her leave, troubled.

location: LANDING AND STAIRCASE IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVEN

text: A FOOTMAN shows. VALMONT and FATHER ANSELME, a stocky Cistercian up the stairs. VALMONT murmurs in FATHER ANSELME's ear and the latter, after a moment's hesitation peels away to sit down on the landing. ’

head_text.subj: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVENING

text: MME DE TOURVEL looks up with a start as her FOOTMAN shows in VALMONT. She stands up, visibly trembling, ethereal with exhaustion. The FOOTMAN waits and is surprised to be dismissed impatiently with a gesture from TOURVEL,
I understand Father Anselme has explained to you the reasons for my visit.  vy Cy 103 Continued 70
Yes. He said you wished to be reconciled with me before beginning instruction with him.
That's right.
But I see no need for formal reconciliation, Monsieur.
No? When I have, as you said, insulted you; and when you have treated me with unqualified contempt.
Contempt?

You run away from my Aunt's house in the middle of the night; you refuse to answer or even receive my letters: and all this after I have shown a restraint of which I think we are both aware. I would call that, at the very least, contempt.
I'm sure you understand me better “than you pretend, Monsieur...
It was me you ran away from, wasn't it?
I had to leave.
And do you have to keep away from me?
I do.
For ever?
I must.
103 71 Continued VALMONT moves away from her now, speaking half to himself it seems.
Well. I'm as unhappy as you could ever have wanted me to be.
I've only ever wanted your happiness. VALMONT runs across to her, falls to his knees and buries his face in her lap.
How can I be happy without you? Cautiously, as if Plunging it in boiling water, MME DE TOURVEL allows her hand to rest for a few seconds on VALMONT's head. He looks up at her fiercely.
I must have you or die. MME DE TOURVEL scrambles to her feet and retreats across the room. VALMONT remains on his knees, his head bowed.
Death it is. She looks back at him, distraught. He rises to his feet, calmer now.
I'm sorry. I'm not used to passion. At least this is the last time. So be calm.
It's difficult when you're in this state, Monsieur.
Yes, well, it won't last very long.
I understood you approved of the choice my duty has compelled me to make.
Yes. And your choice has determined mine.
Whirnh ge whaes
103 72 Continued
The only choice capable of putting an end to my suffering. TOURVEL's eyes are full of fear.
What do you mean? VALMONT puts his hands on her arms and almost shakes her.
Listen. I love you. You've no idea now much. Just remember I've made far more difficult sacrifices than the one I'm about to make. Now goodbye. He pulls away from her, but she clutches at his wrist.
No.
Let me go.
You must listen to me!
I have to go.

No ! During this exchange they have been struggling, he to free himself, she to hang on to him. Now she collapses into his arms and the struggle resolves into a long kiss. Then he sweeps her up in his arms, carries her across the room and gently sets her down on the ottoman. She bursts into tears and clutches on to him as if she's drowning. Eventually he speaks, his voice unusually tender.
Why should you be so upset by the idea of making me happy? Gradually she stops crying, looking up at him.
Yes. You're right. I can't live either unless I make you happy. So I promise. No more refusals and no more regrets.
103 104 105 106 73 Continued He leans in and kisses her gently. Then he looks at her for a second and they begin tearing at one another's clothes, suddenly both equally ravenous.
FATHER ANSELME shifts uneasily, bemused by the unexpected SOUNDS coming from behind the closed doors of the drawing room.

Success!
At last. INT. GRAND SALON Day They're both seated: VALMONT exhilarated, MERTEUIL a trifle frosty.
I arrived about six.
Yes, I think you may omit the details of the seduction, they're never very enlivening: just describe the event itself.
It was...unprecedented. MERTEUIL's facing away from him now, so he's unable to se (or discern from her voice which remains icy calm) that for her, every word is like a dagger.
Really?
It had a kind of charm L don't think I've ever experienced. before.

text: VALMONT. and. TOURVEL entwined on an ottoman, their cloth scattered around.

Which for the first time ever with me outlasted the pleasure itself. She was astonishing.
MME DE TOURVEL sits up now; and VALMONT kneels at her feet, his head in her lap. She strokes his hair, her expression a strange mixture of exaltation and sadness.

CLOSE on VALMONT, as he realises he's allowed himself, pe unwisely, to be carried ‘away.
«-.and for several hours afterwards, I actually meant it.
I see.
It's extraordinary, isn't it?
Is it? It sounds to me perfectly commonplace.
No, no, I assure you. But of course the best thing about it is that I am now in a position to be able to claim my reward.
a] 75 110 Continued MERTEUIL rises. and turns to face him. She considers him coldly for a moment before speaking.
You mean to say you persuaded her to write a letter as well, in the course of this awesome encounter?
No, I didn't necessarily think you were going to be a stickler for formalities.
In any case, I think I may have to declare our arrangement null and void.
What do you mean?
I'm not accustomed to being taken for granted. :
But there's no question of that.
And I've no wish to tear you away from the arms of someone so astonishing.
We've always been frank with one another.

Oh? And who is that?
I am not in the mood for confidences this evening. Don't let me keep you. She rises to her feet decisively. VALMONT follows suit, momentarily at a loss.
VALMONT follows MERTEUIL, as she moves. briskly along the corridor.
You can't seriously imagine IL prefer her to you?
You may genuinely be unaware of this. But I can see quite plainly that you're in love with this woman. VALMONT stops in his tracks, shocked by the suggestion.
No. Not at all. MERTEUIL turns back to him.
Have you forgotten what it's like to make a woman happy: and to be made happy yourself?
I...of course not.
We loved each other once, didn't we? I think it was love. And you made me very happy.
And I could again. We just untied the knot, it was never broken.
Illusions of course, are by their nature sweet.
I have no illusions. I lost them on my travels. Now I want to come home. She shakes her head, a hint of melancholy in her smile.
As they reach the top of the stairs, VALMONT takes her in When they separate, there's tenderness in her eyes. .  Cy
This infatuation: it won't last. But, for the moment, it's beyond my control. She takes her hands away and turns, her expression harden again.
MERTEUIL passes along the corridor, her head sunk in thought. She opens the secret door.
MERTEUIL emerges from her secret door and smiles at someo OUT OF SHOT.
VALMONT sits at his desk, writing.
I'd sacrifice anything or anybody to you, you know that. I genuinely believe I've never been unfaithful to you.
MERTEUIL sits at a small escritoire, writing.
There's no necessity, my dear Vicomte, for you to work on me in this, let's be frank, mechanical ' fashion.. I'm obliged to go away for a couple of weeks, but I'm well aware of our arrangement.
A large carriage passes, MERTEUIL's pale face at the window. There's someone next to her in the shadows, unrecognisahle.
On my return you and L will spend a single night together. I'm sure we shall find it quite sufficient.
VALMONT lies in bed, rereading the letter, a half-smile on his face.

We shall enjoy it enough to regret that it's to be our last; but then we shall remember that regret is an essential component of happiness. All this, of course, providing you are able to procure this famous letter.
VALMONT is pouring some more champagne for EMILIE, when AZOLAN hurries into the room and murmurs in his ear. Whatever he says seems to be an unpleasant surprise to VALMONT.
All right, give me a moment. AZOLAN bows and leaves the room as VALMONT turns to EMILI
A woman?
A lady, we might even say.
Oh, well, then. She swallows her champagne and rises to her feet. Not the one you wrote that letter to?
The very one.
I enjoyed that.
And you proved a most talented desk.
I'd love to see what she looks like.
Well, you can't.
AZOLAN, moving slowly, precedes MME DE. TOURVEL on the st
EMILIE is about to leave by a side-entrance, when VALMONT suddenly checks her, a strange, reckless excitement in hi eyes.
Wait a minute. Do you have an appointment for tonight?
Few friends for dinner.
And after dinner?
Nothing firm. VALMONT opens a drawer and counts out some money.
MME DE TOURVEL pushes past AZOLAN in her eagerness; then stops dead in the entrance to the drawing-room.
MME DE TOURVEL'S P.O.V.: EMILIE is taking the money from VALMONT. .

I'll be there. She walks towards MME DE TOURVEL, staring at her with undisguised fascination. MME DE TOURVEL returns her gaze, miserably confused. VALMONT watches, plainly fascinated. At the last minute, just as she's leaving the room, EMILIE is suddenly convul with mirth. She vanishes, helplessly shaking with laughte VALMONT hurries over to MME DE TOURVEL, who now looks horrified.
This is an unexpected Pleasure.
Evidently. eee lee ‘ay from him as she sper"
80 123) Continued
Take no notice of Emilie; she's notoriously eccentric.
I know that woman.
Are you sure? I'd be surprised.
She's been pointed out to me at the Opera.
Yes, well, she is striking.
She's a courtesan. Isn't she?
I suppose, in a manner of speaking... But MME DE TOURVEL turns and begins to hurry out of the room. VALMONT catches her arm.
I'm sorry I disturbed you.
Of course you haven't disturbed me, I'm overjoyed to see you.
Please let me go now.
No, no, I can't, this is absurd.
Let go! ’ : She wrenches free and he has to put his arms round her and pinions her to prevent her from leaving. By now, she's sobbing blindly.
Let's sit down...
And you will never be received at my house again! She struggles violently and finally goes limp. He helps her over to a sofa and sits her down.  v 123 Continued She watches calm. 81
Now listen.
I don't want your lies and excuses!
Just hear me out, that's all I ask. VALMONT, transfixed, as he speaks with unruffled

Unfortunately, I cannot unlive the years I lived before I met you and during those years, I had a wide acquaintance, the majority of whom were no doubt undesirable in one respect or another. Now it may surprise you to know that Emilie, in common with many others of her. profession and character, is kind-hearted enough to take an interest in those less fortunate than herself. She has, in short, the free time and the inclination to do a great deal of charity work: donations to hospitals, soup for the poor, protection for animals, anything which touches her senti- mental heart. From time to time, I make small contributions to her purse. That's all.
Is that true?

My relations with Emilie have for some years now been quite blameless. She's even done a little secretarial work for me. Since I now know your feelings on the matter, I shall take steps to ensure she is never received here again.
Why did she laugh?
I've no idea.
123 124 82 Continued
Does she know about me?
No doubt she made what, in view of my past, must be regarded as a fair assumption. MME DE TOURVEL seems almost convinced.
I want to believe you.
I knew you were coming up, you were announced. Do you seriously imagine, if I'd felt the slightest guilt about Emilie, I would have allowed you to see her?
I-suppose not.
No. She looks at him, her eyes clear and candid.
I'm sorry. VALMONT flinches, a look of real guilt appearing. He takes her in his arms and she buries her face in his ches weeping softly.
No, no, it's I who must apologise. It was most insensitive of me.
MME DE TOURVEL lies in VALMONT's arms. He looks down at her, profoundly contented.
I didn't think it was possible for me to love you more, but your jealousy... He breaks off, genuinely moved. MME DE TOURVEL looks up at him, speaks with the utmost simplicity.
I love you so much.  a 124 125 126
127 ct a 83 Continued VALMONT draws her up so that she's lying on top of him; and kisses her, his expression uncharacteristically tende
When will you start writing to me again?

head_text.subj: INT. BEDROOM IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S VILLA DAY

text: MME DE MERTEUIL, en deshabille, sits at the dressing- table in her suburban love-nest, reading a letter. In the background a sleeping form, unstirring in the bed.
I have the piece of paper you require and hope I may expect to see you very soon.

head_text.subj: EXT. COURTYARD OF MME DE VOLANGES'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: VALMONT, wrapped up against the blustery wind and wintry rain, encounters the CONCIERGE in the courtyard. He hands over a sum of money and the CONCIERGE admits him by a side-door.
You'll be the very first to hear when I return. In the meantime, I hope you are not neglecting your little pupil.
VALMONT lies with CECILE in her large four-poster. They speak in whispers.
’ But where can Danceny. be?

I told you, I have all my people out looking: and no trace of him. The door suddenly bursts open. CECILE suppresses a shriek VALMONT, who is nearer the door, gets up after a few seco and tiptoes towards the gaping doorway. No one. He closes the door with a Sigh of relief and locks it.
Only the wind. He turns back to discover that CECILE has vanished.
Cy 128 129 130 131 84 Continued

Where are you? There's a groan from the far side of the bed. Hurrying over, VALMONT discovers that CECILE has jammed herself in her panic into the tiny space between the bed and the wall. He helps her up, smiling: but CECILE looks anguished.
Nothing to worry about.
Yes there is. I'm bleeding.

location: ENTRANCE AND COURTYARD OF MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE

text: The same windy and rainy night. MERTEUIL's carriage turns in at the entrance and comes to a stop in the courtyard. The PORTER emerges from his lodge with a large open umbre as FOOTMEN converge on the carriage. Lurking in the archway which leads out to the street is AZOLAN. He moves so as to stay out of sight, peering into the courtyard to try to identify the occupants of the carriage. After a while, he reacts, with an expression of surprise and cynical amusement.

head_text.subj: INT. CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: The house is deserted. VALMONT moves stealthily down the mirrored corridor, surrounded and apparently pursued by h reflections. He stops and hesitates, looking from one mir to another. Then he remembers and applies pressure to one opening it to reveal the stone spiral staircase.
’ VALMONT closes the mirror door behind him. Pitch blacknes He begins to ascend quickly and cautiously.

Candle-light. DANCENY lies in MERTEUIL's arms. They haven't undressed yet. Suddenly, the cupboard door opens and VALMONT appears, giving DANCENY a hideous shock. MERTEUIL covers her surprise far more effectively.
Your porter appears to be under the impression you are still out of town.  ©) cy 131 Continued 85
I have in fact only just returned.
Without attracting the attention of your porter. I think it may be time to review your domestic arrangements.
I'm exhausted. Naturally I instructed the porter to inform casual callers that I was out. VALMONT checks a retort and turns instead, smiling, to DANCENY.
And you here as well, my dear young friend. The porter would seem to be having a somewhat erratic evening.
Oh, well, I, erm, yes.
As a matter of fact, it's you I'm looking for.
Is it?
Mademoiselle Cécile returns to Paris after an absence of over two months. What do you suppose is uppermost in her mind? Answer, of course, the longed-for reunion _ with her beloved Chevalier.
Vicomte, this is no time to make mischief.
Nothing could be further from my mind, Madame.
Go on.
Imagine her distress and alarm when her loved one is nowhere to be found. I've had to do more innwaviocing than ne Tentinng 2 Lee  vy c 131 132 86 Continued
But how is she? Is she all right?
Oh, yes. Well, no, to be quite frank. I'm sorry to tell you she's been ill. DANCENY is horrified.
Calm yourself, my friend, the surgeon has declared her well on the road to recovery. But you can well imagine how desparate I've been to find you.
Of course, my God, how could I not have been here at such a time? How can I ever forgive myself? His voice trails away, as he becomes aware of MERTEUIL's withering glance.
But, look, I hate to be the bearer of bad tidings. All is well now with Cécile, I assure you. And I sharn't disturb you further. He produces a piece of paper from an inside pocket.
It's just that I have something to show the Marquise.
MERTEUIL looks up sharply: he's succeeded in catching her interest.
MERTEUIL finishes reading the letter and hands it back to VALMONT .
I see she writes as badly as she dresses. Before VALMONT can respond, she changes the subject.  iy
uy 132 Continued 87
Is it really true the little one has been ill?
Not so much an illness, more a refurbishment.
What do you mean?
A miscarriage.
Oh, Vicomte, I am sorry. Your son and Bastide's heir.
Isn't there something else we should be discussing?
I do hope you're not going to be difficult about Danceny.
I know Belleroche was pretty limp, but I think you could have found a livelier replacement than that mawkish schoolboy.
Mawkish or not, he's completely devoted to me. And, I suspect, better equipped to provide me with happiness and pleasure than you. In your present mood.
I see. He ‘lapses into an injured silence. Then MERTEUIL smiles coquettishly.
If I thought you would be your Old charming self, I might invite you to visit me one evening next week.
Really?
I still love you, you see, in spite of all your faults and MY camnlainee  y wy 133 134 88
MERTEUIL leads VALMONT, holding his hand. At the top of the grand staircase, he turns to her.

Are you sure you're not going to impose some new condition before you agree to honour your obligation? Pause. MERTEUIL considers how best to respond. Finally she speaks with deadly precision and calm.

I have a friend, who became involved with an entirely un- suitable woman. Whenever any of us pointed this out to him, he invariably made the same feeble reply: it's beyond my control, he would say. He was on the verge of becoming a laughing-stock. At which point, another friend of mine, a woman, decided to speak to him seriously. She explained to him that his name was in danger of being ludicrously associated with this phrase for the rest of his life. So do you know what he did?
I feel sure you're about to tell me.

He went round to see his mistress and bluntly announced he was leaving her. As you might expect, she protested vociferously. But to everything she said, to every objection she made, he simply ' replied: it's beyond my control. Good night. She flits away along the landing. VALMONT stands there for quite some time before beginning his descent. He walks down the stairs, his heart heavy and his head bowed

head_text.subj: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE DAY

text: There's a fire burning in the grate. MME DE TOURVEL paces anxiously up and down. The door opens and the FOOTMAN shows in VALMONT. She runs across to him, unable to conceal her delight and, as the FOOTMAN leaves, she buries herself in his afms. He embraces her, his expression strained and wearv.  q vy 89 134 Continued
You're only five minutes late, but I get so frightened. I become convinced I'm never going to see you again. VALMONT holds her close, his resolution ebbing away. He kisses her lingeringly.
Is it like that for you? VALMONT detaches himself from her, turns away, and takes a few paces, steeling himself. Then he turns back to her, his expression icy.
Yes. At this moment, for example, I'm quite convinced I'm never going to see you again. TOURVEL doesn't understand: but she feels an automatic stab of fear.
What?
I'm so bored, you see. It's beyond my control.
What do you mean?
After all, it's been four months. So, what I say. It's beyond my control.
Do you mean...you don't love me ‘ any more?
My love had great difficulty out- lasting your virtue. It's beyond my control.
It's that woman, isn't it?
You're quite right, I have been deceiving you with Emilie. Among others. It's beyond my control.  w ae) 90 134 Continued
Why are you doing this?

There's a woman. Not Emilie, another woman. A woman I adore. And I'm afraid she's insisting I give you up. It's beyond my control. Suddenly MME DE TOURVEL rushes at him, fists flailing. They grapple silently and grimly for one moment, before she screams at hin.
Liar!
You're right, I ama liar. It's like your fidelity, a fact of life, no more nor less irritating. Certainly, it's beyond my control.
Stop it, don't keep saying that!
Sorry. It's beyond my control. MME DE TOURVEL screams in anguish and collapses, falling against the ottoman.
Why don't you take another lover? She bursts into tears, shaking her head and moaning incoherently.
Just as you like. It's beyond -My control.
Do you want to kill me? VALMONT strides over to her, takes her by the hair and jerks her head up.
Listen. Listen to me. You've given me great pleasure. But I just can't bring myself to regret leaving you. It's the way of the world. Quite beyond my control.
134 135 136 137 138 139 91 Continued He lets her go and she collapses full-length, moaning and sobbing helplessly. He hurries from the room. She remains where she is, utterly distraught.

Outside the door VALMONT has stopped. He can hear the SOUND of MME DE TOURVEL's weeping. He closes his eyes and leans his head back against the door for a moment, his expression tormented and queasy. Then he sets off at a run, leaping down the stairs and out of the front door as fast as he can.
The VICOMTE DE VALMONT's carriage moves through swirling fog.
VALMONT is alone, pale and preoccupied. He taps against the partition and the carriage draws up.

head_text.subj: EXT. ENTRANCE TO MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: VALMONT jumps down from the carriage and calls up to the coachman.
Tomorrow morning, early.
My lord. He flicks his whip and the carriage moves off. VALMONT sets off towards the entrance, a black shape cutting through the fog.

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: The two fires at either end of the great room reflect in the mirrored doors and sparkling chandeliers. Furniture has been drawn up round the fires, forming two islands of objects, leaving the centre of the room a bare arena. MME DE MERTEUIL, alone in the room, sits at a small escritoir, writing. The mirrored doors open and VALMONT appears in the doorway, once again unannounce MERTEUIL looks up: she's unpleasantly surprised to see him, but overcomes her alarp.  92 , 139 Continued ce
This ts not your appointed evening.
No, but I wanted to ask you: that story you told me, how did it end?
I'm not sure I know what you mean.
Well, once this friend of yours had taken the advice of his lady-friend, did she take him back?
Am I to understand...?
The day after our last meeting, I broke with Madame de Tourvel on the grounds that it was beyond my control. et A slow smile of great satisfaction spreads across MERT face. : “
You didn't!
I certainly did.
But how wonderful of you.

You kept telling me my reputation was in danger, but I think this may well turn out to be my most famous exploit. ( believe it ‘ gets a new standard. Only one thing could possibly bring me greater glory.
What's that?
r To win her back. oa MERTEUIL “ You think you could?
I don't see why not.  139 Continued Silence. MERTEUIL, on the other hand, has never seemed more serene. 93
I'll tell you why not: because when one woman strikes at the heart of another, she seldom misses; and the wound is invari- ably fatal.
Is that so?
Oh, yes: I'm also inclined to see this as one of my greatest. triumphs.
There's nothing a woman enjoys as much as a victory over another woman.
Except, you see, Vicomte, my victory wasn't over her.
Of course it was, what do you mean?
It was over you. VALMONT's eyes are suddenly full of fear.

You loved that woman, Vicomte. What's more you still do. Quite desperately. If you hadn't been So ashamed of it, how could you have treated her so viciously? You couldn't bear even the vague possibility of being laughed at. And this has proved something I've always suspected. That vanity and happiness are incompatible. VALMONT is very shaken. He has to make an effort to be able to resume, his voice ragged with strain.
The fact remains, it's now your turn to make a sacrifice.
Is that right?
Danceny must go.  vd 139 Continued 94
Where?
I've been more than patient about this little whim of yours, but enough is enough.

One of the reasons I never re-married, despite a quite bewildering range of offers, was the determination never again to be ordered around. I must therefore ask you to adopt a less marital tone of voice.
She's ill, you know. I've made her ill. For your sake. So the least you can do is get rid of that colourless youth.
I should have thought you'd have had enough of* bullying women for the time being. VALUONT's face hardens.
Right. I see I shall have to make myself very plain. I have come to spend the night. I shall not take at all kindly to being turned away.
I am sorry. ‘I'm afraid I've made other arrangements. A grim satisfaction begins to enliven VALMONT's features.
Ah. I knew there was something.
What?
Danceny isn't coming. Not tonight.
What do you mean? How do you know?
I know because I've arranged for him to spend the night with Cécile.
95 139 Continued Silence. VALMONT smiles.

Now I come to think of it, he did mention he was expected here. But when I put it to him that he really would have to make a choice, I must say he didn't hesitate. He's coming to see you tomorrow to explain; and to offer you, do I have this right, yes, I think I do, his eternal friendship. As you said, he's completely devoted to you.
That's enough, Vicomte.
You're absolutely right. Shall we go up?
Shall we what?
Go up. Unless you prefer this, if memory serves, rather purgatorial sofa.
I believe it's time you were going.
No. I don't think so. We made an arrangement.. I really don't think I can allow myself to be taken advantage of a moment longer.
. Remember I'm better at this than ' you are.

Perhaps. But it's always the best swimmers who drown. Now. Yes or no? Up to you, of course. I merely confine myself to remarking that a no will be regarded as a declaration of war. So. One single word is all that is required.
All right.
139 140 141 142 96 Continued She looks at him evenly for a moment, almost long enough for him to conclude that she has made her answer. But she hasn't. It follows now, calm and authoritative.
War.
There's snow on the ground: and the CAMERA PANS past bare trees in the grey dawn light.

My dear Chevalier Danceny, there is something, as I bid you farewell, that I feel I should tell you. The CAMERA comes to rest on DANCENY, who's in his shirtsl pacing impatiently, pulling on a leather gauntlet. Beside is aman in black, his SECOND, holding an épee. DANCENY ta it from him, his breath rising on the air.

It is not only that he betrayed you with Cécile: it's the pleasure he took in making you ridiculous. ANOTHER ANGLE reveals the whole of the clearing, the snow fresh, if not very deep; and VALMONT, who is calmly makin his selection from a case of épées, held open for him by AZOLAN. He weighs now one and now the other in his hand. Eventually he chooses one and lays it on the ground, whil AZOLAN helps him off with his coat and on with a black gl Then he picks up the sword and approaches DANCENY. They take up the en-garde position. At a sign from AZOLAN, the duel begins, fierce and determined, VALMONT's skill again DANCENY's aggression. For some time, they're evenly match with VALMONT clearly a talented swordsman, looking the mo dangerous. Indeed, quite soon, he seems to have DANCENY a his mercy; but he turns aside at the crucial moment and mowes away, looking surprised at himself.
As in Scene 124, VALMONT draws up MME DE TOURVEL, so that she's lying on top of him.
MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE leave their carriage and move through the snow to the entrance of the convent.  sa 143 144 145 146 147 148 97

head_text.subj: INT. PRIVATE ROOM IN THE CONVENT DAY

text: A NUN shows VOLANGES and CECILE into a plain cell, where MME DE TOURVEL lies in a curtained bed, deathly pale.

VALMONT returns to the attack: they cut and parry with immense energy. Then VALMONT skids in the snow and DANCEN more by luck than good judgment, succeeds in wounding him whichever is not his sword arm. DANCENY immediately withd according to the rules. VALMONT looks down at the wisp of blood staining his torn sleeve.

head_text.subj: INT. MADAME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM IN THE CONVENT DAY

text: The SURGEON's curved blade cuts at the vein on the inside of MME DE TOURVEL's elbow and dark blood begins to flow into a small siiver bowl.

VALMONT shakes his head as if to clear his mind and resum the en-garde position. The duel continues. This time it's DANCENY who looks to have the initiative. VALMONT seems t have lost heart, or even interest; and at one point when a too-enthusiastic attack by DANCENY leaves him wide open VALMONT fails to take advantage of a golden opportunity. This seems to revive VALMONT's vigour for a moment and he beats DANCENY back only to relent at the last minute and turns his back on him. He moves back towards the centre of the clearing, closing his eyes briefly.

head_text.subj: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVENING

text: As in Scene 109, VALMONT kneels with his face in MME DE TOURVEL's lap. ExT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN VALMONT turns back to face DANCENY. Now he hardly seems t be trying at all, simply parrying his thrusts. Then he counter-attacks, but so rashly that he almost seems to run onto DANCENY's blade, which enters him just below the heart. There's a moment of mutual shock, then DANCENY withdraws his sword and VALMONT staggers a couple of step before collapsing. AZOLAN hurries over to him.
I'm cold. AZOLAN runs to get his coat. DANCENY turns to his SECOND.  y 148 98 Continued
Fetch the surgeon.
No, no.
Do as I say! The SECOND hurries away as AZOLAN drapes VALMONT's coat around him. DANCENY stands alone, uncertain.
A moment of your time. DANCENY reluctantly approaches.
Two things: a word of advice, which of course you may ignore, but it is honestly intended; and a request.
Go on.
The advice is: be careful of the Marquise de Merteuil.
You must permit me to treat with scepticism anything you have to say about her.
Nevertheless, I must tell you: in this affair, we are both her creatures. Painfully, he reaches into his coat pocket and brings out a bundle of letters.
As I believe her letters to me will prove. He hands DANCENY the letters. After a moment's thought, DANCENY speaks.
And the request?
I want you to get somehow to see Madame de Tourvel...
I understand she's very ill.

head_text.subj: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM AT THE CONVENT DAY

text: MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE sit watching over MME DE ‘’OUR

That's why this is most important to me. I want you to tell her I can't explain why I broke with her as I did, but that since then my life has been worth nothing. During this, to MME DE VOLANGES's horror, MME DE TOURVEL suddenly wrenches at the bandage at her elbow, opening the wound and causing it to bleed again.
DANCENY rides ‘up to the forbidding walls of the convent and dismounts.
I pushed the blade in deeper than you just have, my boy, and I want you to help me withdraw it.

head_text.subj: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM EVENING

text: DANCENY leans over MME DE TOURVEL, talking to her, unhear MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE wait in the background.

Tell her it's lucky for her that I've gone and I'm glad not to have to live without her. Tell her her love was the only real ‘ happiness I've ever known. MME DE TOURVEL raises a hand and DANCENY stops speaking.
Enough. She looks up at DANCENY.
Draw the curtains. DANCENY rises and draws the curtains on her bed.  wy 152 153 154 100
CLOSE on DANCENY: tears are rolling down his cheeks.
Will you do that for me?
I will. The silence is broken by snatches of birdsong.

head_text.subj: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM EVENING

text: A NUN is lighting candles at the foot of MME DE TOURVEL's bed. Through the curtains, her motionless shape. She's dead. MME DE VOLANGES is by the bed. Ina corner, DANCENY murmurs to CECILE.
I've made copies of her letters and sent them to everyone I could think of.
Letters about me? DANCENY doesn't answer. CECILE shakes her head.
We made it very easy for them.
I'm sorry. You'll never see me again. He hurries from the room. The NUN draws back the curtains as CECILE approaches MME'DE VOLANGES.
I went to see the Mother Superior. I asked her to let me come back ' here. For good. VOLANGES looks at her aghast. CECILE turns away from her and watches as the NUN covers MME DE TOURVEL's waxen face
DANCENY raises a hand to brush away his tears. AZOLAN loo over at him indignantly.
It's all very well doing that now.
Let him be.  154 155 156 157 101 Continued We see VALMONT for the first time in this scene. All around him the snow is red with his blood. He raises a hand towards DANCENY.
He had good cause. It's something I don't believe anyone has ever been able to say about me. Before DANCENY can take his hand, he slumps back. He's dead. .

head_text.subj: INT. MME DE MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY

text: CLOSE on MERTEUIL's face as she utters a great cry of anger and frustration. She sweeps all her perfume-boxes off the dressing-table. Then she smashes everything in the room she can possibly break, ornaments, mirrors, glas jars. She winces suddenly and looks down. She's cut her finger slightly. The sight of her blood seems to calm her She looks up at the circle of SERVANTS, cowering around t margins of the room, appalled.
Get out. All of you. They hurry out in something of a stampede. MERTEUIL stand desolate in a field cf glittering debris. Her head comes down again, contorted with misery and rage.

head_text.subj: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT THE OPERA EVENING

text: It's before curtain-up and MERTEUIL moves to the front of the box to contemplate the house. Three boxes away a dist inguished-looking middle-aged COUPLE are doing the s thing. MERTEUIL bows to them. To her surprise, they turn away from her, ignoring her ostentatiously. She turns to look down at the orchestra, frowning; and becomes aware that the crowd below are murmuring to one another and pointing up at her. Gradually, the hum dies and there's silence in the theatre. Everyone in the stalls is looking up at her. Suddenly, there's a hiss and then, growing qui in volume and intensity, a torrent of hissing and booing.
